sources.data_found: Department of Computer Science Home/About Section: 'We have approximately 350 undergraduate majors and 35 graduate students.'

student_data.notes: Student counts taken directly from the Department of Computer Science 'About' statement ('approximately 350 undergraduate majors and 35 graduate students'). PhD count set to 0 as the department primarily advertises a Master of Science program; doctoral work is typically done via interdisciplinary tracks rather than a dedicated CS PhD.

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: As a member of the Rocky Mountain Advanced Computing Consortium (RMACC), UMT researchers have access to the Alpine cluster at CU Boulder (which contains A100s), but these are not on-premise assets.

gpu_resources.notes: Primary on-premise resource is the 'Griz' cluster. Specs listed as 2 nodes × 4 V100 GPUs = 8 V100 Total. No evidence of newer H100/A100 hardware deployed locally on the research computing public infrastructure pages; heavy reliance on RMACC partnership for higher-tier compute. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

analysis_notes: University of Montana operates a modest local HPC footprint (Griz Cluster) focused on V100 generation hardware. The CS department is primarily undergraduate and Masters focused. Researchers requiring H100/A100 scale are directed to the RMACC Alpine cluster (shared regional resource) rather than local hardware.
